reviews.review_msg: This has been one of the best classes in my undergrad career.

Super supportive and willing to work with students outside of class. Lectures are optional, but super helpful for understanding the material. Highlights the main points of each article through a list of no more than 15 questions, which are discussed in class. Requires a one page summary of each week's readings, marked for completion only.

Took educ 327 with Erin last Fall. She was excellent! Always there for students that needed help. Some of the readings were really dense but she's really good at going over the main points. Go to class! The seminar discussions were very helpful (boring some weeks though depending on the reading). Would totally take a class with her again!

Erin is a phenomenal professor, I have nothing but good things to say about her. The class readings and assignments are very difficult, but Erin is always accessible for extra help. You can tell she really cares about her students and is passionate about teaching.

Jeff made every lecture pretty engaging and fun to listen to. I think it is important to be present for each class, because I think you won't get the full experience of the class otherwise! He is a hard marker tho but he gives a lotta feedback for your assignments. Overall a worthwhile class to take!

I don't recommend this class if it's not required/if you're a slow reader like I am. 3 readings/week ~13-20+ pages each. You'll do well if you write detailed notes of what he says in lecture. Doesn't provide a rubric and gives negative feedback (sometimes personal) but it's because he has very HIGH expectations and wants students to succeed.

Loved this class! First class in my undergrad degree that I never skipped a class. He is very engaging and personable. Makes some funny jokes too.

The course itself is challenging but worth it. Its very rewarding seeing a great grade on my writing assignments
One of the best profs at SFU. Is extremely passionate and knowledgeable. His lectures are insanely interesting and eye-opening. Definitely recommend!

Sugarman was one of the most well-spoken professors I've had at SFU. Although 327 was not an easy class, I think it was one of my favorites. Ask lots of questions and be prepared to apply his feedback to improve your writing. Loved taking this class with Sugarman, highly recommend!!

Best class Ive taken. Sugarman is a great teacher. But you need to do the readings before class and be prepared to discuss them, and you need to listen to his explanations. His expectations are clear and hes very approachable. But this is not a typical easy A education course. Its more like a psych course.

If there is one review you take to heart, let it be this one. Never, never have I felt so confused and dissatisfied with an SFU education course. Sugarman refuses to give detailed criteria and structures the essays around vague prompts. I approached him for help and gained nothing. The mixed reviews on his page speak to how volatile his grading is.

One of the best education courses Ive taken at SFU!! Although some of the concepts are complex, Sugarman explains the course ideas very well and his lectures are super helpful. I recommend taking detailed notes of his lectures, which will be very helpful for writing papers. Also, there are many group and class discussions, which I really enjoyed!

I didnt think he would be such a TOUGH grader. He doesnt provide much context for the questions he assigns, and if you ask for help, he doesnt clarify further & makes you feel stupid for even asking. Hes passionate about what he teaches, and his criticism on the assignments were harsh which made me second guess my writing for every assignment

Sugarman is a very specific prof who knows his content and expects students' to put in the work to do well. However, he is extremely fair and recognizes effort. Make sure to acknowledge and apply his feedback and it is possible to ace the class!! Readings and attendance are crucial as Sugarman clarifies and explains the content. I Recommend!
If you don't give him exactly what he's looking for, you're not going to get a good grade. He roasts you if you understand things slow which was the case for me as well.

Super nice prof! There are quite a few readings for this course (2-3 per class) and weekly summaries for those readings followed by group, then class discussions on them. My advise would be to take detailed notes of the class discussion (having a laptop helps), especially of what Sugarman says about each article, this will help a lot for the papers

Sugarman is the best prof I have ever had in my 4 years of University.  There is a lot of reading each week which is very necessary because the class is almost all discussion.  But he takes the time to make sure everyone understands the concepts thoroughly.  Take good notes of the discussions and you will ace the assignments.
Lots of reading and assignments but he makes things super interesting.

Knows his stuff, lectures insightful Repeats key points, little relation to papers.  Feedback was absolutely necessary to improve. Absolutely no critical feedback namely "?" and "No".  3 large writing assignments, 4,8,12 pg Weekly summaries, discussion in class Readings were 50-60 pages a week, tough Should be W.  Hard marker to the MAX!

I got a good grade but i'm not sure how I feel about this class or the prof. I learned a lot though. Even though the class was philosophy heavy, as someone who had never taken phil, I did not find it to be that difficult. I think I just got lucky. Did minimal work and finished essays the night before and ended up with a decent grade

This is class is more philosophically based rather than EDUC or PSYCH. There are 2 written assignments. The material is difficult to understand. If you don't agree with prof point of view, you WILL fail. These are marked based on clarity and understanding of theories. He doesn't offer help with the course. Majority of the class failed the midterm.

This class was really difficult because of the philosophical approach. It is interesting material but it becomes tough with all the readings since it will take many times to read over them. If you do not perform well on the written assignments, then thats that.

This course is intensely Philosophical. If you are a PSYCH/EDUC student, DO NOT take this course. No final BUT 2 big papers that are very hard. If you do bad on the papers he will not help you do better. The readings are complex so prepare to re-read. Writing intensive, with weekly papers.

One of the worst classes I've ever taken. It is very philosophically heavy, and he emphasizes this component and his biases. If you enjoy phil, go for it. If you are a psych/educ student who prefers practical applicable knowledge, avoid this class. He's a tough marker, and unclear educator who doesn't tie any information into an applicable context.

Please don't shy away from a challenge with this course.  As a psych major it was one of the few education courses that really kept me challeneged and I thoroughly enjoyed it.  I highly recommend Sugarman, not only does he keep things interesting but he is passionate about the material and very knowledgeable.  Great class/great guy all around!!

Knows his stuff and as long as you pay attention take notes and ask him questions about stuff you're not sure about you'll be fine. He's super passionate and intellectual about the course and when you do well in the course it's highly rewarding cause it can be challenging.
A little intimidating at first but this prof is passionate about what he does. You won't look at your "self" the same way ever again... guaranteed!

This course was the most challenging education course that I have taken so far at SFU. He is very passionate about the subject. Although it is not one of the easy and relaxing course, it is always good to chellenge yourself!

Whoever said he was easy was wrong. I didn't learn much in this class from him. No notes were given from him. It was pretty much a discussion every class with group work. His marking is not good. He doesn't award any half-marks.  Don't take him if you want to get at least a B-.
